stem: For each client finding, click to specify if it is consistent with Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) Bronchiolitis, Dehydration, or both conditions.

patient.chiefComplaint: Increased work of breathing and poor feeding.

itemContext.sbar: 6-month-old male presenting with increased work of breathing and poor feeding for the past 2 days. Mother reports decreased wet diapers. Temperature is 101.2°F (38.4°C) rectally. Auscultation reveals diffuse wheezing and crackles. Retractions are noted. Oxygen saturation is 90% on room air.

rationale.correct: Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) Bronchiolitis: Wheezing, Crackles, Retractions, Hyperinflation on Chest X-ray. Dehydration: Dry mucous membranes, Decreased skin turgor, Elevated Sodium, Elevated BUN/Creatinine. Both: Tachycardia, Elevated Respiratory Rate, Fever, Poor Feeding, Decreased Wet Diapers, Lethargy.
rationale.incorrect: Confusing dehydration and RSV symptoms can lead to improper management. For example, attributing wheezing solely to dehydration may delay necessary respiratory support. Conversely, overlooking dehydration can worsen respiratory distress due to thickened secretions and reduced perfusion.
clinicalPearls: RSV is a common cause of bronchiolitis in infants, characterized by inflammation and obstruction of the small airways.
Dehydration can significantly impact respiratory function by thickening secretions and reducing the effectiveness of mucociliary clearance.
Assessment of fluid status and respiratory effort are crucial in managing infants with bronchiolitis.

questionTrap.description: Students may attribute all respiratory symptoms solely to RSV and fail to recognize the contribution of dehydration to the overall clinical picture.
questionTrap.areaOfConfusion: Differentiating between respiratory distress caused by RSV and that exacerbated by dehydration.
